commit_message:
Refactor volume connection cleanup out of _post_live_migration

The _post_live_migration method is huge and hard to review/test/
maintain in isolation so we need to break down the complexity.
To that end this change refactors the source host volume connection
cleanup code into another method which also allows us to simplify
a couple of unit tests that target that specific set of code.
The error handling in that new method is tested by the functional
test class LiveMigrationCinderFailure.

Change-Id: Id0e8b1c32600d53382e5ac938e403258c80221a0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/41/682741/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _post_live_migration_remove_source_vol_connections( self, context, instance, source_bdms): """Disconnect volume connections from the source host during _post_live_migration. :param context: nova auth RequestContext :param instance: Instance object being live migrated :param source_bdms: BlockDeviceMappingList representing the attached volumes with connection_info set for the source host """ # Detaching volumes. connector = self.driver.get_volume_connector(instance) for bdm in source_bdms: if bdm.is_volume: # Detaching volumes is a call to an external API that can fail. # If it does, we need to handle it gracefully so that the call # to post_live_migration_at_destination - where we set instance # host and task state - still happens. We need to rethink the # current approach of setting instance host and task state # AFTER a whole bunch of things that could fail in unhandled # ways, but that is left as a TODO(artom). try: if bdm.attachment_id is None: # Prior to cinder v3.44: # We don't want to actually mark the volume detached, # or delete the bdm, just remove the connection from # this host. # # remove the volume connection without detaching from # hypervisor because the instance is not running # anymore on the current host self.volume_api.terminate_connection(context, bdm.volume_id, connector) else: # cinder v3.44 api flow - delete the old attachment # for the source host self.volume_api.attachment_delete(context, bdm.attachment_id) except Exception as e: if bdm.attachment_id is None: LOG.error('Connection for volume %s not terminated on ' 'source host %s during post_live_migration: ' '%s', bdm.volume_id, self.host, six.text_type(e), instance=instance) else: LOG.error('Volume attachment %s not deleted on source ' 'host %s during post_live_migration: %s', bdm.attachment_id, self.host, six.text_type(e), instance=instance) # Disconnect volumes from this (the source) host. self._post_live_migration_remove_source_vol_connections( ctxt, instance, source_bdms)

We need to rethink the # current approach of setting instance host and task state # AFTER a whole bunch of things that could fail in unhandled # ways, but that is left as a TODO(artom). try: if bdm.attachment_id is None: # Prior to cinder v3.44: # We don't want to actually mark the volume detached, # or delete the bdm, just remove the connection from # this host. # # remove the volume connection without detaching from # hypervisor because the instance is not running # anymore on the current host self.volume_api.terminate_connection(ctxt, bdm.volume_id, connector) else: # cinder v3.44 api flow - delete the old attachment # for the source host self.volume_api.attachment_delete(ctxt, bdm.attachment_id) except Exception as e: if bdm.attachment_id is None: LOG.error('Connection for volume %s not terminated on ' 'source host %s during post_live_migration: ' '%s', bdm.volume_id, self.host, six.text_type(e), instance=instance) else: LOG.error('Volume attachment %s not deleted on source ' 'host %s during post_live_migration: %s', bdm.attachment_id, self.host, six.text_type(e), instance=instance)

commit_message:
Fix update share network tests and skip exception issue

After fixing a bug that was allowing share network update when it
shouldn't, the test that validates the share network creation and
update started failing. An additional validation was introduced and
it caused the new bug. This patch fixes the test and make it work
properly.
In addition this patch fixes test classes that are raising a skip
exception inside the setUpClass function and failing due to testtool
issue #272.

Closes-Bug: #1849728
Closes-Bug: #1849377
Related-Bug: #1846836
Co-Author: Carlos Eduardo <ces.eduardo98@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I5b27ee4a9e844ea48dc9324bcf38f5767223717f
(cherry picked from commit 0ca91287acffece4f78451e160fafa040a988f5a)

commit_message:
Evaluate input expression should check the in_context

The workflow in the test fails because contextView
does not evaluate in_context

Closes-Bug: #1850315
Change-Id: I54a4cd38e962d363fd2626476bcae9ec0aa8dad6

commit_message:
api-ref: remove mention about os-migrations no longer being extended

When 2.23 was implemented people thought the GET /os-migrations API
would no longer be extended, but it has twice since then with 2.59
and 2.66 so let's remove the misleading comment with 2.23 in the REST
API version history doc.

Change-Id: I76e5238fdf8e96062dc8bd23777c358c572a5dc5

commit_message:
Convert ServiceNetMap evals to hiera interpolation

Since https://review.openstack.org/#/c/514707/ added the net_ip_map
to hieradata, we can look up the per-network bind IPs via hiera
interpolation instead of heat map_replace.

In some cases the ServiceNetMap lookup is used for other things,
but anywhere we make use of the "magic" translation via NetIpMap
is changed the same way.

This will enable more of the configuration data to be exposed per
role vs per node in a future patch (to simplify our ansible
workflow).

Co-authored-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ie3da9fedbfce87e85f74d8780e7ad1ceadda79c8
(cherry picked from commit 3a7baa8fa6fa8dd6735f38d6236e8a2cb5d34659)

commit_message:
Switch to opensuse-15 nodeset

opensuse-150 nodeset is referring to openSUSE 15.0, which is still in
maintenance but openSUSE 15.1 has been released already. "opensuse-15"
is going to refer to the "latest openSUSE 15.x" build released and
working for OpenStack going forward, so add this nodeset and use
it by default going forward.

Update all jobs. There were already a few opensuse-15 jobs, so remove
some opensuse-150 jobs since we can use the -15 ones instead.

Change-Id: I695b07933ffcbdf51213442155a9a0e2eab12bbc
(cherry picked from commit af588a44aa51fb610b8ef8ab8bb36daaebdb3f69)

commit_message:
Exclude sushy 1.9.0

sushy 1.9.0 contains critical Redfish message registry bugs which cause
the Ironic generic 'redfish' hardware type (driver) to not work against
at least some Dell EMC hardware.

More specifically, it causes all generic Ironic driver interface
implementations which use the Distributed Management Task Force (DMTF)
Redfish protocol, including 'redfish*' and 'idrac-redfish*', to not
work. Those interface implementations are supported by the generic
'redfish' and 'idrac' drivers, respectively.

Story: 2006702
Task: 37317
Change-Id: I0efe08b1d10bde8ce06314eb84bae0286ce75e21
(cherry picked from commit dae99a97409ce42b3ae5a7344fa8fc01514a0b7c)

commit_message:
undercloud-setup: fixed two runtime warnings

Non fatal but confusing and avoidable error:
/bin/sh: /etc/ci/mirror_info.sh: No such file or directory

[DEPRECATION WARNING]: Invoking "pip" only once while using a loop via
squash_actions is deprecated. Instead of using a loop to supply multiple items
and specifying `name: "{{ item }}"`, please use `name: ['pip', 'setuptools']`
and remove the loop. This feature will be removed in version 2.11. Deprecation
warnings can be disabled by setting deprecation_warnings=False in ansible.cfg

Change-Id: I1495dd11405613b7ca63e81cfec8c3eead2dbece

added_lines: # Settings specific to os_tempest # Settings for os_tempest run_tempest: >- {% if release not in ['pike', 'queens', 'rocky', 'stein'] -%} false {%- else -%} true {%- endif -%} use_os_tempest: >- {% if release not in ['pike', 'queens', 'rocky', 'stein'] -%} true {%- else -%} false {%- endif -%} # It will create a public network name 'public' using os_tempest tempest_interface_name: public # In order to have a public network with external connectivity, we need to use # flat network type tempest_public_net_provider_type: flat # It is the physical network name through which public network will be created # having connectivity with external world. tempest_public_net_physical_name: datacentre # Setting the tempest_cidr as it is required while creating public subnet from which # floating IPs gets assigned tempest_cidr: '10.0.0.0/24' # In order to create a private network, fs020 is based on OVN, geneve should be used # as private network type tempest_private_net_provider_type: geneve tempest_private_net_seg_id: '' tempest_install_method: distro # Having tempest_network_ping_gateway set to true allows to ping any of the IP from # router to find out network related issue in the deployment early tempest_network_ping_gateway: true # It is the python-tempestconf profile which also consumes tempest-deployer-input file tempest_tempestconf_profile: debug: true create: true deployer-input: "{{ ansible_user_dir }}/tempest-deployer-input.conf" os-cloud: "{{ tempest_cloud_name }}" out: "{{ tempest_workspace }}/etc/tempest.conf" network-id: "{{ tempest_neutron_public_network_id }}" overrides: "{{ tempest_tempest_conf_overrides | default('omit') }}" # Whitelist should be empty tempest_test_whitelist: '' # Run skiplist as a whitelist tempest_run_skip: True tempest_test_blacklist: "{{ tempest_whitelist }}" # Set tempest concurrency tempest_run_concurrency: 3 # List of tempest plugins to install tempest_services: - cinder - neutron

commit_message:
token: consistently decode binary types

Ensure that any binary types unpacked from message payloads
are correctly converted from binary to text type.

Under Python 3 msgpack returns the serialized input as a
byte string. Similar to other msgpack'd values in the payload,
we need to explicitly decode it to a string value.

This is specifically more of an issue under Python 3; however
the decode operation is safe back to Python 2 so there is no
need to limit the decode codepath to just Python 3.

Conflicts:
    keystone/token/token_formatters.py

Note: the file conflict is caused by patch
I9529d6bee3e5bb1f618f40f225f69e2ad7e3f64a which is only present in
stable/train.

Change-Id: Ib1073acf5677a60714d0a386de3bcd14ce6cd134
Closes-Bug: 1832265
(cherry picked from commit ffa0918f5a92fd18c86703916d768012b0bea61b)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/70/690070/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: except (ValueError, TypeError): # ValueError: this might not be a UUID, depending on the # situation (i.e. federation) # TypeError: the provided value may be binary encoded # in which case just return the value (i.e. Python 3) @classmethod def _convert_or_decode(cls, is_stored_as_bytes, value): """Convert a value to text type, translating uuid -> hex if required. :param is_stored_as_bytes: whether value is already bytes :type is_stored_as_bytes: six.boolean :param value: value to attempt to convert to bytes :type value: six.text_type or six.binary_type :rtype: six.text_type """ if is_stored_as_bytes: return cls.convert_uuid_bytes_to_hex(value) elif isinstance(value, six.binary_type): return value.decode('utf-8') return value user_id = cls._convert_or_decode(is_stored_as_bytes, user_id) user_id = cls._convert_or_decode(is_stored_as_bytes, user_id) user_id = cls._convert_or_decode(is_stored_as_bytes, user_id) project_id = cls._convert_or_decode(is_stored_as_bytes, project_id) user_id = cls._convert_or_decode(is_stored_as_bytes, user_id) project_id = cls._convert_or_decode(is_stored_as_bytes, project_id) group_id = cls._convert_or_decode(is_stored_as_bytes, group_id) user_id = cls._convert_or_decode(is_stored_as_bytes, user_id) idp_id = cls._convert_or_decode(is_stored_as_bytes, idp_id) user_id = cls._convert_or_decode(is_stored_as_bytes, user_id) scope_id = cls._convert_or_decode(is_stored_as_bytes, scope_id) idp_id = cls._convert_or_decode(is_stored_as_bytes, idp_id) user_id = cls._convert_or_decode(is_stored_as_bytes, user_id) project_id = cls._convert_or_decode(is_stored_as_bytes, project_id) access_token_id = cls._convert_or_decode(is_stored_as_bytes, access_token_id) user_id = cls._convert_or_decode(is_stored_as_bytes, user_id) user_id = cls._convert_or_decode(is_stored_as_bytes, user_id) project_id = cls._convert_or_decode(is_stored_as_bytes, project_id) app_cred_id = cls._convert_or_decode(is_stored_as_bytes, app_cred_id)
deleted_lines: except ValueError: # this might not be a UUID, depending on the situation (i.e. # federation) if is_stored_as_bytes: user_id = cls.convert_uuid_bytes_to_hex(user_id) if is_stored_as_bytes: user_id = cls.convert_uuid_bytes_to_hex(user_id) if is_stored_as_bytes: user_id = cls.convert_uuid_bytes_to_hex(user_id) if is_stored_as_bytes: project_id = cls.convert_uuid_bytes_to_hex(project_id) if is_stored_as_bytes: user_id = cls.convert_uuid_bytes_to_hex(user_id) if is_stored_as_bytes: project_id = cls.convert_uuid_bytes_to_hex(project_id) if is_stored_as_bytes: group_id = cls.convert_uuid_bytes_to_hex(group_id) if is_stored_as_bytes: user_id = cls.convert_uuid_bytes_to_hex(user_id) if is_stored_as_bytes: idp_id = cls.convert_uuid_bytes_to_hex(idp_id) else: idp_id = idp_id.decode('utf-8') if is_stored_as_bytes: user_id = cls.convert_uuid_bytes_to_hex(user_id) if is_stored_as_bytes: scope_id = cls.convert_uuid_bytes_to_hex(scope_id) else: # NOTE(lbragstad): We assembled the token payload scope as a tuple # (False, domain_id) for cases like (False, 'default'), since the # default domain ID isn't converted to a byte string when it's not # in UUID format. Despite the boolean indicator in the tuple that # denotes if the value is stored as a byte string or not, msgpack # apparently returns the serialized input as byte strings anyway. # For example, this means what we though we were passing in as # (False, 'default') during token creation actually comes out as # (False, b'default') in token validation through msgpack, which # clearly isn't correct according to our boolean indicator. This # causes comparison issues due to different string types (e.g., # b'default' != 'default') with python 3. See bug 1813085 for # details. We use this pattern for other strings in the payload # like idp_id and protocol_id for the same reason. if six.PY3 and isinstance(scope_id, six.binary_type): scope_id = scope_id.decode('utf-8') if is_stored_as_bytes: idp_id = cls.convert_uuid_bytes_to_hex(idp_id) else: if six.PY3 and isinstance(idp_id, six.binary_type): idp_id = idp_id.decode('utf-8') if is_stored_as_bytes: user_id = cls.convert_uuid_bytes_to_hex(user_id) if is_stored_as_bytes: project_id = cls.convert_uuid_bytes_to_hex(project_id) if is_stored_as_bytes: access_token_id = cls.convert_uuid_bytes_to_hex(access_token_id) if is_stored_as_bytes: user_id = cls.convert_uuid_bytes_to_hex(user_id) if is_stored_as_bytes: user_id = cls.convert_uuid_bytes_to_hex(user_id) if is_stored_as_bytes: project_id = cls.convert_uuid_bytes_to_hex(project_id) if is_stored_as_bytes: app_cred_id = cls.convert_uuid_bytes_to_hex(app_cred_id)

commit_message:
Switch to the opensuse-15 nodeset

We are trying to deprecate the opensuse-150 label type in favor of the
opensuse-15 label. The reason for this is opensuse 15, like centos,
doesn't support its older point releases and instead expects users to
keep up to date on its minor updates. This allows us to carry one fewer
image in opendev and ensures we are testing supported releases.

Change-Id: Ifa3e79514f52bc78dbaf6496188075c24366d86c

commit_message:
WIP: SchedulerReportClient.set_aggregates_for_provider

Introduce SchedulerReportClient.set_aggregates_for_provider, which
accepts a provider UUID and list of aggregate UUIDs to push back to the
placement API.  On success, the local ProviderTree cache is updated
appropriately.  On failure, an exception is raised.  If the failure was
a conflict (409), the exception is a subclass of PlacementAPIConflict so
that the caller may decide to refresh and retry.

Depends-On: cdent's to-be-proposed placement API microversion for RP
            aggs+generation
WIP: replace 1.__AGG_GENERATION_MICROVERSION__ with real microversion
     from the above.

Change-Id: I91679a92f926d486ca6092242253a3d4f31f7c3b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/95/532995/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def set_aggregates_for_provider(self, rp_uuid, aggregates, generation): """Replace a provider's aggregates with those specified. The provider must exist - this method does not attempt to create it. :param rp_uuid: The UUID of the provider whose aggregates are to be updated. :param aggregates: Iterable of aggregates to set on the provider. :param generation: The generation of the provider as last retrieved from placement. Used by the placement API to detect concurrent updates. :raises: ResourceProviderUpdateConflict if the provider's generation doesn't match the generation specified. Callers may choose to retrieve the provider and its associations afresh and redrive this operation. :raises: ResourceProviderUpdateFailed on any other placement API failure. """ url = '/resource_providers/%s/aggregates' % rp_uuid aggregates = aggregates or [] payload = { 'resource_provider_generation': generation, 'aggregates': aggregates, } resp = self.put(url, payload, version='1.__AGG_GENERATION_MICROVERSION__') if resp.status_code == 200: json = resp.json() self._provider_tree.update_aggregates( rp_uuid, json['aggregates'], generation=json['resource_provider_generation']) return # Some error occurred; log it msg = ("[%(placement_req_id)s] Failed to update aggregates to " "[%(aggs)s] for resource provider with UUID %(uuid)s. Got " "%(status_code)d: %(err_text)s") args = { 'placement_req_id': get_placement_request_id(resp), 'uuid': rp_uuid, 'aggs': ','.join(aggregates), 'status_code': resp.status_code, 'err_text': resp.text, } LOG.error(msg, args) # If a conflict, raise special conflict exception if resp.status_code == 409: raise exception.ResourceProviderUpdateConflict( uuid=rp_uuid, generation=generation, error=resp.text) # Otherwise, raise generic exception raise exception.ResourceProviderUpdateFailed(url=url, error=resp.text) @safe_connect

commit_message:
Add cluster_id to action filter in API

Current, an action was created haven't information of a cluster.
When a specific action is created, we do not know what action this action takes
in a cluster and when we execute the query API:

GET http://senlin_host:8777/actions

so many actions are returned even though we can limit using parameters
such as name, target, action, status combined with limit and marker.
But, we can't just get the actions executed in a particular cluster.
So, I want us to be able to do this by enabling the query with a cluster_id parameter.
To accomplish this, I need to modify the schema of
action models and action tables in the database of senlin service.

Change-Id: I49d172414eecf9158192cf0869abb91822ee2226

commit_message:
[vmwareapi] Expose cpu model on homogeneous cluster; Refactoring code;

Change-Id: I4665333efe35ef3a94b8bd47468a3e4938c50854
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/88/561588/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_log import log as logging from oslo_vmware import vim_util as vutil self._cpu_model = None data["cpu_model"] = self.to_cpu_model() def to_cpu_model(self): max_objects = 100 vim = self._session.vim property_collector = vim.service_content.propertyCollector traversal_spec = vutil.build_traversal_spec( vim.client.factory, "c_to_h", "ComputeResource", "host", False, []) object_spec = vutil.build_object_spec( vim.client.factory, self._cluster, [traversal_spec]) property_spec = vutil.build_property_spec( vim.client.factory, "HostSystem", ["hardware.cpuPkg", "hardware.cpuInfo", "config.featureCapability"]) property_filter_spec = vutil.build_property_filter_spec( vim.client.factory, [property_spec], [object_spec]) options = vim.client.factory.create('ns0:RetrieveOptions') options.maxObjects = max_objects pc_result = vim.RetrievePropertiesEx(property_collector, specSet=[property_filter_spec], options=options) result = [] """ Retrieving needed hardware properties from ESX hosts """ with vutil.WithRetrieval(vim, pc_result) as pc_objects: for objContent in pc_objects: props_in = {prop.name: prop.val for prop in objContent.propSet} processor_type = None cpu_vendor = None hardware_cpu_pkg = props_in.get("hardware.cpuPkg", [])[0] if hardware_cpu_pkg and hardware_cpu_pkg[0]: t = hardware_cpu_pkg[0] processor_type = t.description cpu_vendor = t.vendor.title() features = [] for featureCapability in props_in.get("config.featureCapability", []): for feature in featureCapability[1]: if feature.featureName.startswith("cpuid."): if feature.value == "1": features.append(feature.featureName.split(".", 1)[1].lower()) props = { "model": processor_type, "vendor": cpu_vendor, "features": sorted(features) } hardware_cpu_info = props_in.get("hardware.cpuInfo", None) if hardware_cpu_info: props["topology"] = { "cores": hardware_cpu_info.numCpuCores, "sockets": hardware_cpu_info.numCpuPackages, "threads": hardware_cpu_info.numCpuThreads } result.append(props) equal = True """ Compare found ESX hosts """ if len(result) > 1: for i in range(len(result) - 1): if result[i] == result[i + 1]: continue else: equal = False break if not equal: self._cpu_model = "CPU's for this cluster have different values!" elif result: self._cpu_model = result[0] return self._cpu_model

subject: Fix wrong disk size for sparse flat files
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-11-12 18:17:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/c7f5f81b355e30d7e4fb67d036077f08649602fd', 'message': "Fix wrong disk size for sparse flat files

The libvirt driver creates flat disks as sparse by default. However,
it always returns over_committed_disk_size=0 for flat disks
in _get_instance_disk_info(). This incorrect data ends up being reported
to the scheduler in the libvirt driver's get_available_resource() via
_get_disk_over_committed_size_total(). _get_instance_disk_info() should use
allocated blocks, not file size, when calculating over_commited_disk_size for
flat disks.

Closes-Bug: #1593155

Change-Id: I593a913779746730587df313a24e64680891e515

commit_message:
Fix wrong disk size for sparse flat files

The libvirt driver creates flat disks as sparse by default. However,
it always returns over_committed_disk_size=0 for flat disks
in _get_instance_disk_info(). This incorrect data ends up being reported
to the scheduler in the libvirt driver's get_available_resource() via
_get_disk_over_committed_size_total(). get_instance_disk_info() should use
allocated blocks, not file size, when calculating over_commited_disk_size for
flat disks. We can just use qemu-img tool to file disk size same as qcow2.

Closes-Bug: #1593155

Change-Id: I593a913779746730587df313a24e64680891e515
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/73/396873/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Adds new molecule testing for tripleo-container-manage

This test ensure the "create" part is working fine with an easy and
simple container. The container-create and default scenario have been
consoldated so its running one complete test for now.

Change-Id: I9139c7b63c15739a1a95d913acb1128af299ce97
Co-Authored-By: Emilien Macchi <emilien@redhat.com>
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

Config options related to imagecache should be removed.
However, it is not currently entirely possible due to
the upgrade issue - if someone is doing a leap frog
upgrades and would not run Ocata for a longer period of
time there is high probability that the imagechace file
will still be around after the upgrade.

This patch removes ``checksum_base_images`` and
``checksum_interval_seconds``. Default value of
``remove_unused_resized_minumum_age_seconds`` has been
changed from 3600 to 0 to address the problem described
above. This option should be removed after Ocata.

Change-Id: I7b422f3bb4d61f91574be4df612fa7db5f83533a
Implements: blueprint centralize-config-options-ocata

commit_message:
conf: Remove libvirt imagecache

Config options related to imagecache should be removed. However, it is
not currently entirely possible due to the upgrade issue - if someone is
doing a leap frog upgrades and would not run Ocata for a longer period
of time there is high probability that imagecache files will still be
around after the upgrade.

Removes ``checksum_base_images`` and ``checksum_interval_seconds``, and
set the default value of ``remove_unused_resized_minumum_age_seconds``
to 0 (from 3600) to address the problem described above. This option is
also deprecated to allow for its removal after Pike.

Change-Id: I7b422f3bb4d61f91574be4df612fa7db5f83533a
Implements: blueprint centralize-config-options-pike
Co-Authored-By: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Fix amp failover where failover already failed

If a failover ran on an amphora and was unsuccessful and reverted, it
would mark the amp status "DELETED" and un-busy the health record.
It would then be picked up on the next failover check, start failing
over, and break early since it appeared to be "unallocated".

Also, housekeeping can now clean up expired amphora records based on the
amphora's updated_at time instead of the health record's time, which
means the records won't be immediately cleaned up anymore after they go
through failover flows.

Conflicts:
    octavia/controller/worker/controller_worker.py
    octavia/controller/worker/flows/amphora_flows.py
    octavia/tests/unit/controller/worker/flows/test_amphora_flows.py
    octavia/tests/unit/controller/worker/test_controller_worker.py
    tools/create_flow_docs.py

Change-Id: I848b7fc69b977fcb39f8a07e2ea5fc7bd37b5c7a
(cherry picked from commit 96cce3ed74c63e5756e216a8e48c60de09b027c2)

subject: Fix nova scheduler down after first docker restart
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-10-24 14:03:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible/commit/1d509622ba46d28b34c9be073cecf2762efeb861', 'message': 'Restart nova scheduler to refresh cell cache

Reloading nova-scheduler is necessary after new cells have been created
to refresh the cell cache.  Ideally we would send a SIGHUP, but due
to a Docker bug (https://github.com/moby/moby/issues/11065) this will
cause the container to be stopped if we restart Docker or reboot the
server.

This change switches to restarting the nova-scheduler container.

Change-Id: Ief73bbd24568d6941384ea3330ab45f11aa42d37
Closes-Bug: #1845244

SIGHUP to the container because it will mark it as
stopped.
This patch sends the signal directly to the process,
bypassing Docker.

'changed_when: false' is also removed from the
relevant task as it definitely changes the state.
In the future we could do the refresh only if
there really is a need for another one.

[1] https://github.com/moby/moby/issues/11065

commit_message:
Fix nova scheduler down after first docker restart

Due to a Docker bug [1] we cannot use Docker to send
SIGHUP to the container because it will mark it as
stopped.
This patch sends the signal directly to the process,
bypassing Docker.

'changed_when: false' is also removed from the
relevant task as it definitely changes the state.
In the future we could do the refresh only if
there really is a need for another one.

[1] https://github.com/moby/moby/issues/11065

Change-Id: Ief73bbd24568d6941384ea3330ab45f11aa42d37
Co-authored-by: Radosław Piliszek <radoslaw.piliszek@gmail.com>
Closes-Bug: #1845244

commit_message:
prevent removing numa_topology usage info from DB

Basically this is reverting patch of below.

commit b6edbce9b3b092581eeda6be15059a1ba2bfcfdf
Author: He Jie Xu <hejie.xu@intel.com>
Date:   Thu Sep 8 19:46:24 2016 +0800

    Ensure ResourceProvider/Inventory created before add
    Allocations record

Because resources in the _copy_resources() only contains basic
information about host numa_toplogy without usage, updating DB at
here is to overwrite previous NUMA usage information in the DB.
The usage will never be recovered thereafter since
_resource_change() in the _update() regards as there are no changes
indeed.

Closes-Bug: #1729621
Closes-Bug: #1739349
Related-Bug: #1621437
Change-Id: I6a488cb9c2744cd34209f718462f00160849d968
Signed-off-by: Minho Ban <mhban@samsung.com>

subject: [placement] fix rp create failed when late placement endpoint
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-07-13 16:35:59.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/084b845c996427ebb5d87c78ffa67e4f748341bc', 'message': 'fix resource-provider regist failed in db while placement endpoint created after nova-compute start

1.if rp create failed because of endpoint, report-client reload
  keystone session and raise exception. rt catch the exception
  and init the old_resource, cause _update() call report-client
  again next period.

2.delete two duplicate _update() in _init_compute_node(), because
  _update() while called at end of _update_available_resource.
  Too many period db actiions in large scale clusters increase the
  load of database.

Change-Id: Id54d06b13c9f655d78c7ea19313958060076a9a2
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-07-13 16:38:21.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/80c5541e4bf934ca478fa22cc5c3a2f03c8df5b0', 'message': 'fix resource-provider regist failed in db while placement endpoint created after nova-compute start

1.if rp create failed because of endpoint, report-client reload
  keystone session and raise exception. rt catch the exception
  and init the old_resource, cause _update() call report-client
  again next period.

2.delete two duplicate _update() in _init_compute_node(), because
  _update() while called at end of _update_available_resource.
  Too many period db actiions in large scale clusters increase the
  load of database.

commit_message:
[placement] fix rp create failed when late placement endpoint

If rp create failed because the placement endpoint is not yet available,
the report-client reload keystone session and raise exception. rt catch
the exception and init the old_resource, cause _update() call
report-client again next period.

Related-Bug: #1697825

Change-Id: Id54d06b13c9f655d78c7ea19313958060076a9a2

added_lines: # os_tempest setting # Settings for os_tempest run_tempest: >- {% if release not in ['pike', 'queens', 'rocky', 'stein'] -%} false {%- else -%} true {%- endif -%} use_os_tempest: >- {% if release not in ['pike', 'queens', 'rocky', 'stein'] -%} true {%- else -%} false {%- endif -%} # It will create a public network name 'public' using os_tempest tempest_interface_name: public # In order to have a public network with external connectivity, we need to use # flat network type tempest_public_net_provider_type: flat # It is the physical network name through which public network will be created # having connectivity with external world. tempest_public_net_physical_name: datacentre # Setting the tempest_cidr as it is required while creating public subnet from which # floating IPs gets assigned tempest_cidr: '10.0.0.0/24' # In order to create a private network, fs01 is based on OVN, geneve should be used # as private network type tempest_private_net_provider_type: geneve tempest_private_net_seg_id: '' tempest_install_method: distro # Having tempest_network_ping_gateway set to true allows to ping any of the IP from # router to find out network related issue in the deployment early tempest_network_ping_gateway: true # It is the python-tempestconf profile which also consumes tempest-deployer-input file tempest_tempestconf_profile: debug: true create: true deployer-input: "{{ ansible_user_dir }}/tempest-deployer-input.conf" os-cloud: "{{ tempest_cloud_name }}" out: "{{ tempest_workspace }}/etc/tempest.conf" network-id: "{{ tempest_neutron_public_network_id }}" overrides: "{{ tempest_tempest_conf_overrides | default('omit') }}" tempest_tempest_conf_overrides: auth.use_dynamic_credentials: 'True' auth.tempest_roles: "'Member, creator'" # Running all api and scenario tests tempest_test_whitelist: - 'api' - 'scenario' # Set tempest concurrency tempest_run_concurrency: 3 # List of tempest plugins to install tempest_services: - cinder - horizon - neutron

commit_message:
A way to keep the UEFI nvram contents on libvirt+qemu/kvm

Nova support boot UEFI instance on libvirt+qemu/kvm, but stop and
start the UEFI instance will lead to redefine the instance domain,
every time undefine will delete the uefi nvram, it stores the boot
information of the UEFI instance as MBR boot sector, define a
domain will create a new file from template, so instance will be
lost the boot information at next boot.

This commit is intended to solve this problem, this nvram needs to
be a local file, so we can backup the nvram file before undefined
and restore it before next boot.

Change-Id: If481a093c9816656cbfd936336b41d92ea5f28ba
Closes-Bug: #1633447
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/06/471706/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

use_uefi: self.assertTrue(mock_exec.called) if use_rbd: mock_import.assert_called_once_with(instance, mock.ANY, 'disk.nvram') else: self.assertTrue(mock_copyfile.called) if dest: mock_copy_image.assert_called_once_with("/foo/bar", drvr.image_backend.path, host=dest, on_execute=mock.ANY, on_completion=mock.ANY) def test_backup_nvram_use_rbd(self): self.test_backup_nvram(use_uefi=False) def test_restore_nvram(self, use_uefi=True, use_rbd=False): drvr = libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver(fake.FakeVirtAPI(), False) CONF.libvirt.virt_type = 'kvm' drvr._restore_nvram(instance) if use_uefi: if use_rbd: mock_exec.assert_has_calls([ mock.call('rbd', 'export', '--pool', 'rbd', mock.ANY, "/foo/bar", run_as_root=True), mock.call('chown', mock.ANY, "/foo/bar", run_as_root=True), mock.call('chmod', mock.ANY, "/foo/bar", run_as_root=True)]) else: mock_exec.assert_has_calls([ mock.call('cp', drvr.image_backend.path, "/foo/bar", run_as_root=True), mock.call('chown', mock.ANY, "/foo/bar", run_as_root=True), mock.call('chmod', mock.ANY, "/foo/bar", run_as_root=True)]) def test_restore_nvram_use_rbd(self): self.test_restore_nvram(use_rbd=True) def test_restore_nvram_with_no_uefi_image(self): self.test_restore_nvram(use_uefi=False)

subject: Add granularity to os-services API
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-06-27 20:36:27.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/c4d38a24ff3a83c7ab6433543c97fef52584168d', 'message': "Add granularity to os-services API

The Nova Compute services (os-services) API is not granular enough in
the sense that multiple APIs check the same policy action for list,
update, and delete. This does not allow operators with strict
security requirements to have different roles that can perform
certain os-services APIs but not others - it currently is all or
nothing. As it currently stands, listing, updating, and deleting
compute services checks the single policy action
'os_compute_api:os-services' - which prevents operators who want read
only roles or other sub-admin type roles. To further achieve RBAC
granularity, this patch adds new policy actions to the os-services
API.

To address backwards compatibility, this patch leverages the
'verify_deprecated_policy' method [1] which allows the existing
policy action 'os_compute_api:os-services' or the new actions to be
used.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/policy.py#L230

Closes-Bug: #1778994

Change-Id: Ie8579300792d3ceab1e5c37eade47e599207666f
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2018-06-28 21:49:38.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/bf34004e58079935983e89e8d367a453f37420d4', 'message': "Add granularity to os-services API

To address backwards compatibility, this patch leverages the

"}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2018-07-06 22:40:40.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/c702b7cdfba583af63738a6636175261b07054cf', 'message': "Add granularity to os-services API

The Nova Compute services (os-services) API is not granular enough in
the sense that multiple APIs check the same policy action for list,
update, and delete. This does not allow operators with strict
security requirements to have different roles that can perform
certain os-services APIs but not others - it currently is all or
nothing. As it currently stands, listing, updating, and deleting
compute services checks the single policy action
'os_compute_api:os-services' - which prevents operators who want read
only roles or other sub-admin type roles. To further achieve RBAC
granularity, this patch adds new policy actions to the os-services
API.

To address backwards compatibility, the following deprecation strategy is
implemented:

  - Introduce the new rules with new default roles
  - Keep enforcing the old rules with same default for deprecation period
  - Give warning for user about switching to old rules to new rules
  - Note we will enforce the old rules as it is till deprecation period and
    new rule as soft enforcement only as it should not effect any user for
    deprecation period
  - After deprecation period. we will remove the old rules and keep enforcing
      the new rules only
~
Closes-Bug: #1778994

Change-Id: Ie8579300792d3ceab1e5c37eade47e599207666f

commit_message:
Add granularity to os-services API

The Nova Compute services (os-services) API is not granular enough in
the sense that multiple APIs check the same policy action for list,
update, and delete. This does not allow operators with strict
security requirements to have different roles that can perform
certain os-services APIs but not others - it currently is all or
nothing. As it currently stands, listing, updating, and deleting
compute services checks the single policy action
'os_compute_api:os-services' - which prevents operators who want read
only roles or other sub-admin type roles. To further achieve RBAC
granularity, this patch adds new policy actions to the os-services
API.

To address backwards compatibility, the following deprecation strategy is
implemented:

  - Introduce the new rules with new default roles
  - Keep enforcing the old rules with same default for deprecation period
  - Give warning for user about switching to old rules to new rules
  - Note we will enforce the old rules as it is till deprecation period and
    new rule as soft enforcement only as it should not affect any user for
    deprecation period
  - After deprecation period, we will remove the old rules and keep enforcing
    the new rules only

Closes-Bug: #1778994
Partially Implements: bp granular-api-policy
Change-Id: Ie8579300792d3ceab1e5c37eade47e599207666f

added_lines: from nova.policies import basefrom nova import policy # TODO(rb560u): remove this check in future release using_old_action = \ policy.verify_deprecated_policy(services_policies.BASE_POLICY_NAME, services_policies.POLICY_ROOT % 'index', base.RULE_ADMIN_API, context) if not using_old_action: context.can(services_policies.POLICY_ROOT % 'index') # TODO(rb560u): remove this check in future release using_old_action = \ policy.verify_deprecated_policy(services_policies.BASE_POLICY_NAME, services_policies.POLICY_ROOT % 'update', base.RULE_ADMIN_API, context) if not using_old_action: context.can(services_policies.POLICY_ROOT % 'update') # TODO(rb560u): remove this check in future release using_old_action = \ policy.verify_deprecated_policy(services_policies.BASE_POLICY_NAME, services_policies.POLICY_ROOT % 'delete', base.RULE_ADMIN_API, context) if not using_old_action: context.can(services_policies.POLICY_ROOT % 'delete') # TODO(rb560u): remove this check in future release using_old_action = \ policy.verify_deprecated_policy(services_policies.BASE_POLICY_NAME, services_policies.POLICY_ROOT % 'update', base.RULE_ADMIN_API, context) if not using_old_action: context.can(services_policies.POLICY_ROOT % 'update')

commit_message:
Fix update share network tests and skip exception issue

After fixing a bug that was allowing share network update when it
shouldn't, the test that validates the share network creation and
update started failing. An additional validation was introduced and
it caused the new bug. This patch fixes the test and make it work
properly.
In addition this patch fixes test classes that are raising a skip
exception inside the setUpClass function and failing due to testtool
issue #272.

Closes-Bug: #1849728
Closes-Bug: #1849377
Related-Bug: #1846836
Co-Author: Carlos Eduardo <ces.eduardo98@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I5b27ee4a9e844ea48dc9324bcf38f5767223717f

commit_message:
For instances end up in cell0, set its availability_zone to None.

Instances that have not yet been created will be created in cell0,
after the availability zone is changed, but the available_zone in
the instances database of the instance does not change, which will
cause fail to filter the list of instances by the available zone.

Change-Id: I417318b98b7db77b22c768c7114f33c890616174

commit_message:
Assess ceph request status until it is complete.

Due to a change in the ceph-client interface *1 the
storage-ceph.pools.available flag can be lost when the charm is
upgraded from an old version to the current version. To account for
this check the request status whenever there is an outstanding
ceph request.

*1 https://github.com/openstack/charm-interface-ceph-client/blame/master/requires.py#L107

Change-Id: I179df45af2fb2d4723cd579a1070ece0d18b5002
Closes-Bug: #1850618

commit_message:
Rollback instance vm_state to original where instance claims failed

When rebuild_claim or resize_claim failed because of
ComputeResourceUnavailable exception, we set the vm_state
to original vm_state.

Change-Id: I32f574d4742d0bd1e0d60196cc0756ec6ece7988
Closes-Bug: #1784983

subject: Fix instance delete stuck in deleting task_state
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-08-30 08:24:42.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/b2e6a49964e7285ae901c39c918a9c9acb56c07e', 'message': "Fix instance delete stuck in deleting task_state

During instance deletion if rabbitmq-server crashes
after setting instance task_state to 'DELETING' or
'SOFT_DELETING'. That instance will get deleted only
on nova-compute restart.

Extend periodic method _run_pending_deletes to delete
instances stuck in 'DELETING' or 'SOFT_DELETING' task_state.

Record the timestamp of last valid delete request in
instance's system_metadata field. This timestamp is used to
judge whether the deletion is time out and the instance
need to be deleted in _run_pending_deletes.

Rreferences:
* https://review.openstack.org/#/c/281782
* https://review.openstack.org/#/c/294491

Change-Id: I43e995c3f5d71e56f0b0e136e45a307e329d7ae4
Closes-Bug: #1543511

need to be deleted in _run_pending_deletes.

commit_message:
Fix instance delete stuck in deleting task_state

During instance deletion if rabbitmq-server crashes
after setting instance task_state to ``DELETING`` or
``SOFT_DELETING``. That instance will get deleted only
on nova-compute restart.

1) Add periodic task _cleanup_instances_stuck_in_deleting_task
to delete instances stuck in ``DELETING`` or ``SOFT_DELETING``
task_state. The periodic interval is
``running_deleted_instance_poll_interval`` conf option.

2) Soft delete instance when nova-compute restart if the
instance's task_state is ``SOFT_DELETING``.

Rreferences:
* https://review.openstack.org/#/c/281782
* https://review.openstack.org/#/c/294491

Change-Id: I43e995c3f5d71e56f0b0e136e45a307e329d7ae4
Closes-Bug: #1543511
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/84/598084/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Catch the not found exception when powering off a vmware instance

Bug description:
when creating a vmware instance from a volume is failed,
vm goes to error state, the volume is in "in use" state,
and after deleting the vm, the state of the volume is still in
"in use" and can't be deleted.
The reason of this bug is : When VM failed to boot, an operation of
detach volume will be execute, but there is no VM in vmware ESXI, so ,
when powering off this instance in _detach_instance_volumes(),
it will raise an exception: InstanceNotFound.
Finally, the volume is in "in use" status.
Though this change , we catch the InstanceNotFound exception,
and let the flow in destroy() go on,
so that the status of volume can be set to "avalible"

Closes-Bug:#1774137

Change-Id: I987d9b46c82b66ecc0ef2453bdd7fce6d3a7810d

commit_message:
Add compute service support for attach/detach root volume

This patch bumps compute service version to 38 to indicate
that attach/detach root volume is supported. It will be checked
in compute/api.py when handling root volume when attaching/detaching.

This patch also added a new method reset_fields_for_detached_root_bdm()
to BlockDeviceMapping obj, it will be used in attach/detach root
volume workflow since in these cases, we want to keep the BDM record
but reset some fields.

Implements: blueprint detach-boot-volume

Change-Id: I073da489005d8f746efcbefd413d20b978be44fa
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/50/614750/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: MIN_COMPUTE_ATTACH_DETACH_ROOT_VOLUME = 37 if bdm.is_root: bdm.cleup_fields_for_root_bdm() bdm.save() else: bdm.destroy() supports_multiattach=False, is_root=False): def detach_volume(self, context, instance, volume, is_root=False): if is_root: service = objects.Service.get_by_compute_host( context, instance.host) if service.version < MIN_COMPUTE_ATTACH_DETACH_ROOT_VOLUME: raise exception.DetachAttachRootVolumeNotYetSupported
deleted_lines: bdm.destroy() supports_multiattach=False): def detach_volume(self, context, instance, volume):

subject: Detach/Attach root volume API changes

commit_message:
Detach/Attach root volume API changes

Added support for detaching a root volume and attach a root
volume by specify ``is_root=True`` when attaching. These
actions will be only allowed to perform on instances in
``SHELVED_OFFLOADED`` status. If try to request ``unshelve`` an
instance without root volume, the corresponding API will reply
``HTTP 409``.

Added support for including the ``boot_index`` field in the responses
of:

* POST /servers/{server_id}/os-volume_attachments (attach)
* GET /servers/{server_id}/os-volume_attachments (list)
* GET /servers/{server_id}/os-volume_attachments/{volume_id} (show)

Implements: blueprint detach-boot-volume

Change-Id: I759d4a7cce56047d21e91c2135e0414c243f99fd

commit_message:
Fix update share network functional test

After fixing a bug that was allowing share network update when it
shouldn't, the test that validates the share network creation and
update started failing. An additional validation was introduced in
the fix for this bug, and this was this test failure cause. This
patch fixes the test and make it work properly.

Change-Id: Id588ee74ac50b5e63c83df5cde3328861e3f3d76
Closes-Bug: #1849377

subject: Make multi-platform support more maintainable
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-08-16 15:07:04.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ansible-role-container-registry/commit/f8824d3be4816fa2b94d3e186076d8bb4ba588dd', 'message': 'Improve multi-platform support more maintainable

Avoids use of extensive platform dependenc conditionals inside the
tasks as they easily get out of control when trying to support
multiple distributions and releases.

This patterns allows us to add support for new distributions by
only changing the vars/ configurations.

Based on https://docs.sbarnea.com/ansible/ansible-disto-vars

Change-Id: I0b9cfd056338fb0f529b69cf52b405e0fa5368e9

commit_message:
Make multi-platform support more maintainable

Avoids use of extensive platform dependenc conditionals inside the
tasks as they easily get out of control when trying to support
multiple distributions and releases.

This patterns allows us to add support for new distributions by
only changing the vars/ configurations.

Based on https://docs.sbarnea.com/ansible/distro-vars

Change-Id: I0b9cfd056338fb0f529b69cf52b405e0fa5368e9

commit_message:
libvirt: Introduce SMM (System Management Mode) config class

The SMM[2] hypervisor feature is a prerequisite to support UEFI Secure
Boot with OVMF (Open Virtual Machine Firmware), which is aimed to be
added as a future future[1].

This shows up in a Nova guest XML as:

    ...
    <features>
      <acpi/>
      <apic/>
      <smm state='on'/>
    </features>
    ...

The purpose[3] of SMM in this context is:

    "(virtual) hardware separation between the runtime guest OS and the
    firmware (OVMF), with the intent to make Secure Boot actually
    secure, by preventing the runtime guest OS from tampering with the
    variable store and S3 [meaning: suspend to RAM] areas."

[1] (WIP spec) https://review.openstack.org/#/c/506720/ -- Add ability
    for OVMF Secure Boot
[2] http://wiki.osdev.org/System_Management_Mode
[3] https://github.com/tianocore/edk2/tree/master/OvmfPkg

Change-Id: I1a30d8ed4ebe6c22eefd2d79322a24ae08aa7216

commit_message:
Correct ovn-dbs upgrade image id variable

In I8b5b25d03b86b2c44b2d47e5a0624e7dd13873da the variable
ovn_dbs_image_id was renamed to old_ovn_dbs_image_id but
one instance of it was left behind. This patch corrects
that.

Related-Bug: #1838971
Closes: rhbz#1758578
Change-Id: I5735210aad47411fdeb62d4dab45b1150ec3ea04

commit_message:
Switch to IPA-builder for building ironic-python-agent

Also update the documentation to purge any mentions of CoreOS images
and the deprecated ironic-agent element.

Change-Id: I09018e451e698a7c6b99106b64c87a526cc959d5

subject: multi numa nfv testing job
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-09-02 14:05:08.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/2f81720bb79b4dbb355b4800c9e47d7557073ad9', 'message': '[WIP] multi numa nfv testing job

- This change adds two new job definitions for a single and multi node
  nfv job.
- This change adds two new nodeset that target the multi node lables
  "ubuntu-bionic-expanded" provided by fortnebula.

The fortnebula(FN) ubuntu-bionic-expanded lable provide a dual
numa guest with 16G of ram and 8CPU arraned in a toplogy
of 2 sockets each with 2 core each with 2 hyperthreads.

while this might change in the future, combined with the fact that
FN also provides nested vert it allows testing of cpu pinning,
hugepages, multi numa guest, realtime instance and other nfv features.

This job use those feature to add basic first party testing of nfv featuers.
This job can be extended in the future to do more advanced testing by
leveraging the whitebox tempest plugin.

Change-Id: I76ccf842e142ea91890abfb61d44b0725e9ee750

  nfv job.
- This change adds two new nodeset that target the multi node lables
  "ubuntu-bionic-expanded" provided by fortnebula.

The fortnebula(FN) ubuntu-bionic-expanded lable provide a dual
numa guest with 16G of ram and 8CPU arraned in a toplogy
of 2 sockets each with 2 core each with 2 hyperthreads.

while this might change in the future, combined with the fact that
FN also provides nested vert it allows testing of cpu pinning,
hugepages, multi numa guest, realtime instance and other nfv features.

This job use those feature to add basic first party testing of nfv featuers.
This job can be extended in the future to do more advanced testing by
leveraging the whitebox tempest plugin.

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/672595/
Change-Id: I76ccf842e142ea91890abfb61d44b0725e9ee750

commit_message:
multi numa nfv testing job

- This change adds two new job definitions for a single and multi node
  nfv job.
- This change adds two new nodeset that target the multi node lables
  "ubuntu-bionic-expanded" provided by fortnebula.

The fortnebula(FN) ubuntu-bionic-expanded lable provide a dual
numa guest with 16G of ram and 8CPU arraned in a toplogy
of 2 sockets each with 2 core each with 2 hyperthreads.

while this might change in the future, combined with the fact that
FN also provides nested vert it allows testing of cpu pinning,
hugepages, multi numa guest, realtime instance and other nfv features.

This job use those feature to add basic first party testing of nfv featuers.
This job can be extended in the future to do more advanced testing by
leveraging the whitebox tempest plugin.

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/640021/
Change-Id: I76ccf842e142ea91890abfb61d44b0725e9ee750
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/56/679656/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - nodeset: name: nfv-multi-numa nodes: - name: controller # note this is a FN specific lable with 16GB of ram and the following extra specs # hw:numa_nodes=2 hw:cpu_sockets=2 hw:cpu_threads=2 hw:cpu_cores=2 label: ubuntu-bionic-expanded groups: # Node where tests are executed and test results collected - name: tempest nodes: - controller # Nodes running the compute service - name: compute nodes: - controller - nodeset: name: nfv-multi-numa-multinode nodes: - name: controller label: ubuntu-bionic-expanded - name: compute label: ubuntu-bionic-expanded groups: # Node where tests are executed and test results collected - name: tempest nodes: - controller # Nodes running the compute service - name: compute nodes: - controller - compute # Nodes that are not the controller - name: subnode nodes: - compute # Switch node for multinode networking setup - name: switch nodes: - controller # Peer nodes for multinode networking setup - name: peers nodes: - compute - job: name: tempest-nfv-multi-numa # this is too high but it will do for now timeout: 10800 nodeset: nfv-multi-numa parent: tempest-all irrelevant-files: &nfv-irrelevant-files # NOTE(sean-k-mooney): This job has its own irrelevant-files # section so that we only run it on changes to networking, # object and libvirt code; we don't need to run this on # all changes, nor do we run it in the gate. # We also run it on change to the .zuul.yaml to ensure it does # not break. - ^(?!nova/network/.*)(?!nova/objects/.*)(?!nova/virt/libvirt/.*)(?!\.zuul\.yaml).*$ pre-run: - playbooks/nfv/nfv.yaml vars: # we should increase this once the job works tempest_concurrency: 1 tempest_test_regex: '^(?!.*(?:tempest\.scenario\.test_network_advanced_server_ops\.TestNetworkAdvancedServerOps\.test_server_connectivity_suspend_resume.*)|(?:tempest\.scenario\.test_network_advanced_server_ops\.TestNetworkAdvancedServerOps\.test_server_connectivity_pause_unpause.*))((?:tempest\.scenario\.test_network_basic_ops.*)|(?:tempest\.scenario\.test_network_advanced_server_ops.*)).*$' tempest_black_regex: 'mtu|keypair|images|negative|disk|quota' devstack_services: dstat: flase etcd3: flase peakmem_tracker: flase rabbit: true tls-proxy: true # disable swift s-account: false s-container: false s-object: false s-proxy: false # disable cinder services c-api: false c-bak: false c-sch: false c-vol: false cinder: false devstack_localrc: USE_PYTHON3: true LIBVIRT_TYPE: kvm devstack_local_conf: post-config: $NOVA_CONF: DEFAULT: # NOTE(sean-k-mooney): we have 8 cpus in the gate vcpu_pin_set: 1-7 compute: cpu_shared_set: 0 scheduler: enabled_filters: 'AvailabilityZoneFilter,ComputeFilter,ComputeCapabilitiesFilter,ImagePropertiesFilter,ServerGroupAntiAffinityFilter,ServerGroupAffinityFilter,SameHostFilter,DifferentHostFilter,PciPassthroughFilter,NUMATopologyFilter' max_attempts: 10 libvirt: cpu_mode: custom cpu_model: kvm64 workarounds: enable_numa_live_migration: true test-config: $TEMPEST_CONFIG: compute: flavor_ref: 420 flavor_ref_alt: 840 # network tweaks should not be needed but don't hurt. network: ping_timeout: 180 connect_timeout: 180 ssh_timeout: 300 volume-feature-enabled: backup: False compute-feature-enabled: # turn on this later once basic job works and enable cinder volume_backed_live_migration: False resize: True scheduler_enabled_filters: 'AvailabilityZoneFilter,ComputeFilter,ComputeCapabilitiesFilter,ImagePropertiesFilter,ServerGroupAntiAffinityFilter,ServerGroupAffinityFilter,SameHostFilter,DifferentHostFilter,PciPassthroughFilter,NUMATopologyFilter' - job: name: tempest-nfv-multi-numa-multinode parent: tempest-nfv nodeset: nfv-multi-numa-multinode vars: # increase this later when this job works tempest_concurrency: 1 group-vars: subnode: devstack_services: rabbit: false # - integrated-gate-compute # - openstack-cover-jobs # - openstack-lower-constraints-jobs # - openstack-python-jobs # - openstack-python3-train-jobs # - periodic-stable-jobs # - publish-openstack-docs-pti # - release-notes-jobs-python3# # We define our own irrelevant-files so we don't run the job # # on things like nova docs-only changes. # - ironic-tempest-ipa-wholedisk-bios-agent_ipmitool-tinyipa: # voting: false # irrelevant-files: *dsvm-irrelevant-files # - devstack-plugin-ceph-tempest: # voting: false # irrelevant-files: *dsvm-irrelevant-files # - neutron-grenade-multinode: # irrelevant-files: *dsvm-irrelevant-files # - neutron-tempest-linuxbridge: # irrelevant-files: # # NOTE(mriedem): This job has its own irrelevant-files section # # so that we only run it on changes to networking and libvirt/vif # # code; we don't need to run this on all changes, nor do we run # # it in the gate. # - ^(?!nova/network/.*)(?!nova/virt/libvirt/vif.py).*$ # - nova-grenade-multinode # - nova-live-migration # - nova-lvm # - nova-multi-cell # - nova-next # - nova-tox-functional # - nova-tox-functional-py36 # - tempest-integrated-compute: # irrelevant-files: *dsvm-irrelevant-files # - tempest-slow-py3: # irrelevant-files: *dsvm-irrelevant-files # - grenade-py3: # irrelevant-files: *dsvm-irrelevant-files # - tempest-ipv6-only: # irrelevant-files: *dsvm-irrelevant-files - tempest-nfv-multi-numa-multinode: irrelevant-files: *nfv-irrelevant-files
deleted_lines: - integrated-gate-compute - openstack-cover-jobs - openstack-lower-constraints-jobs - openstack-python-jobs - openstack-python3-train-jobs - periodic-stable-jobs - publish-openstack-docs-pti - release-notes-jobs-python3 # We define our own irrelevant-files so we don't run the job # on things like nova docs-only changes. - ironic-tempest-ipa-wholedisk-bios-agent_ipmitool-tinyipa: irrelevant-files: *dsvm-irrelevant-files - devstack-plugin-ceph-tempest: voting: false irrelevant-files: *dsvm-irrelevant-files - neutron-grenade-multinode: irrelevant-files: *dsvm-irrelevant-files - neutron-tempest-linuxbridge: irrelevant-files: # NOTE(mriedem): This job has its own irrelevant-files section # so that we only run it on changes to networking and libvirt/vif # code; we don't need to run this on all changes, nor do we run # it in the gate. - ^(?!nova/network/.*)(?!nova/virt/libvirt/vif.py).*$ - nova-grenade-multinode - nova-live-migration - nova-lvm - nova-multi-cell - nova-next - nova-tox-functional - nova-tox-functional-py36 - tempest-integrated-compute: irrelevant-files: *dsvm-irrelevant-files - tempest-slow-py3: irrelevant-files: *dsvm-irrelevant-files - grenade-py3: irrelevant-files: *dsvm-irrelevant-files - tempest-ipv6-only: irrelevant-files: *dsvm-irrelevant-files

subject: Add exact match aggregate image properties matcher/filter
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-08-17 20:17:25.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/93a6131cfc099cfa13a8b5f2ddd2116277e56067', 'message': 'Add exact match aggregate image properties matcher/filter

This filter is a variant of the AggregateImagePropertiesIsolation
but is distinct enough that it should likely be its own thing.

The reasoning behind it is that the existing filter is a little
to tolerant of missing image properties (when you really want it
to match exactly) and to setup your aggregates and images with that
filter is very tedious, fragile, and error prone.

So instead of that filter, this filter uses some of the same concepts
but is less tolerant of missing image properties (for example when
you setup a windows only hypervisor set you do not want other images
with various other properties to end up there).

Change-Id: I9ba17489b914edeb7e882380d98ac497ddc0b383
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2018-08-17 20:18:07.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/5934ce001edca550a4d461a4cea8388711f4335e', 'message': 'Add exact match aggregate image properties matcher/filter

Co-author: Elancheran Subramanian <esubramanian@godaddy.com>

Change-Id: I9ba17489b914edeb7e882380d98ac497ddc0b383

Co-author: Elancheran Subramanian <esubramanian@godaddy.com>

Change-Id: I9ba17489b914edeb7e882380d98ac497ddc0b383
'}]
commit_message:
Add exact match aggregate image properties matcher/filter

This filter is a variant of the AggregateImagePropertiesIsolation
but is distinct enough that it should likely be its own thing.

The reasoning behind it is that the existing filter is a little
to tolerant of missing image properties (when you really want it
to match exactly) and to setup your aggregates and images with that
filter is very tedious, fragile, and error prone.

So instead of that filter, this filter uses some of the same concepts
but is less tolerant of missing image properties (for example when
you setup a windows only hypervisor set you do not want other images
with various other properties to end up there).

Co-author: Elancheran Subramanian <esubramanian@godaddy.com>

Change-Id: I9ba17489b914edeb7e882380d98ac497ddc0b383
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/67/593167/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from oslo_log import log as logging from nova.scheduler import filters from nova.scheduler.filters import utils LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class AggregateExactImagePropertiesIsolation(filters.BaseHostFilter): """AggregateExactImagePropertiesIsolation works with image properties. NOTE(harlowja): this differs from `AggregateImagePropertiesIsolation` in that that filter has issues (config namespacing doesn't work due to the object layer...) and that that filter is more tolerant of images missing desired metadata attributes (this one is not). So for example say you have a windows only hypervisor aggregate and you have a image tagged with windows and a bunch of images that are not tagged with windows (perhaps they are linux or bsd); using the other filter would allow these other images to boot on your windows only hypervisor aggregate (unless you go through the pain of tagging all the other images as non-windows). This filter though would for a windows aggregate only allow images that tagged with windows through (and not ones that are not tagged). This makes it much easier to use this filter and its capabilities (ie so that you as an operator/user do not need to remember to tag images with all properties and anti-properties). """ # Aggregate data and instance type does not change within a request run_filter_once_per_request = True RUN_ON_REBUILD = True def host_passes(self, host_state, spec_obj): """Checks a host in an aggregate that aggregate metadata key/value match *exactly* with image properties. """ image_props = spec_obj.image.properties if spec_obj.image else {} agg_metadata = utils.aggregate_metadata_get_by_host(host_state) missing = set() invalid = [] for key, options in agg_metadata.items(): try: prop = image_props.get(key) except AttributeError: missing.add(key) else: if not prop: missing.add(key) else: # NOTE(sbauza): Aggregate metadata is only strings, we # need to stringify the property to match with the option # TODO(sbauza): Fix that very ugly pattern matching if str(prop) not in options: invalid.append((key, prop, options)) if missing or invalid: if missing: LOG.debug("Host '%(host)s' has metadata key(s) %(missing)s" " that are not present in the image properties.", {"host": host_state.host, "missing": missing}) if invalid: # TODO(harlowja): maybe do this in one bulk message? for key, prop, options in invalid: LOG.debug("%(host_state)s fails image aggregate" " properties requirements. Image/metadata" " '%(key)s' property value '%(value)s' does" " not match allowed metadata %(options)s.", {'host_state': host_state, 'value': prop, 'options': options, 'key': key}) return False else: # Ok, it passes; this can happen if there are no values in the # aggregate metadata or everything that was present matched as # we wanted it to. return True

commit_message:
Update min tox version to 2.0

The commands used by constraints need at least tox 2.0.  Update to
reflect reality, which should help with local running of constraints
targets.

Change-Id: I77a5cbfdb6e58b81618b579c58b2af1aaf849b6c
Closes-Bug:  #1801484

commit_message:
Migrate to Zuul v3 native jobs

This corrects the path handling in the CI and removes a lot of
redundancy in the CI definitions. Also adds fixed log collection
from https://review.opendev.org/#/c/649526/ to make the CI pass.

Removes handling of ZUUL_CHANGES. It is not present in new jobs,
and its use case in Bifrost is completely unclear.

Eventually, we should rewrite the whole test-bifrost.sh in ansible,
but that's a much bigger task.

Change-Id: Id893e816a7806e7d75282628817288d8a34ab8af

commit_message:
Refactor CONTRIBUTING.rst

I've been noticed that this file is very OpenStack generic and doesn't help
contributors to find the Nova-specific documentation about our contributing
process.
Here is a first take of what I think we can document easily without maintaining
too hardly but comments or other patch sets are welcome.

Change-Id: I36cf1d030627101d21cb143a8b900a1c78d19fca
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/70/640970/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Nova has its own development process that is documented in this page: https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/contributor/process.html Any change to the Nova repository is tied to a specific question : - is it a bugfix ? - is it a trivial implementation not requiring design discussion ? - it is a refactoring or feature implementation that has an operator impact ? If after reading the contributor documentation above you still have questions, don't hesitate to come by the IRC #openstack-nova channel and raise your point, someone will help you.
deleted_lines: If you would like to contribute to the development of OpenStack, you must follow the steps in this page: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html Once those steps have been completed, changes to OpenStack should be submitted for review via the Gerrit tool, following the workflow documented at: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html#development-workflow Pull requests submitted through GitHub will be ignored. Bugs should be filed on Launchpad, not GitHub: https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova

commit_message:
Add apply_cells to nova-manage

This adds a new apply_cells method to the nova-manage commands that
reads in a specification file (json or yaml) and sets up the
configurations based on the specifications within the file. This
feature matches cell_mappings to specifications based on its name and
will "make-it-so" for cell_mappings by:
* create_cell (spec exists with a name not already in cell_mappings),
* update_cell (spec and mapping exist, but have different values),
* delete_cell (spec file does not have a matching cell by name).

There is a --dry-run argument that can be used to see what would change
without actually performing any modifications.

This should allow automated systems that want to source control (git or
inventory generated) how their cells are setup and managed.

Change-Id: I7a60a02637d85f576d4be6d9ea8a5e2a01360d0c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/87/568987/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import osimport yaml @action_description( _("Takes a file with a list of cell specifications and applies it to " "the system. This matches a cells by name, creates cells that do " "not exist, updates matched cells where information has changed, " "and deletes cells that are not within this list. The result " "returns the max return code from all of the functions it " "performed.")) @args('--cell-specs-file', metavar='<path_to_specs_file>', help=_("A json or yaml list of cell specifications that contain: " "name (used as the unique key to the cell), " "database_connection, transport_url, disabled. Sample " "file: "''' [ { "name": "cell0", "database_connection": "<database_connection_url0>", "transport_url": null, "disabled": false }, { "name": "cell1", "database_connection": "<database_connection_url1>", "transport_url": "<transport_url1>", "disabled": false }, { "name": "cell2", "database_connection": "<database_connection_url2>", "transport_url": "<transport_url2>", "disabled": true } ]''')) @args('--dry-run', action='store_true', help=_('When set, simply outputs what changes would have been ' 'performed without actually applying the changes.')) @args('--verbose', action='store_true', help=_('More verbose output depending on sub-functions called.')) @args('--force', action='store_true', help=_('Force changes where applicable. This is forwarded on to ' 'this class sub-functions that use it (Default False)')) def apply_cells(self, cell_specs_file=None, verbose=False, dry_run=False, force=False): """Reads a cell spec file and applies specs until cell mappings match. :param cell_specs_file: The file to read the cell specifications from. :param verbose: More verbose output depending on sub-functions called. :param dry_run: Run this in "test" mode showing changes but not applying them. :param force: Apply force for functions requesting it (delete_cell) :return: The maximum return result of all of the sub-functions that were called while synchronizing cells to match the specifications. """ if not cell_specs_file: print(_('Must specify --cell-specs-file as a path to a ' 'file with a json or yaml list of cells.')) return 1 if not os.path.exists(cell_specs_file): print(_('The path specified by --cell-specs-file does not point ' 'to a valid file location.')) return 1 # Retrieve all the specs, validate and index by name specs = self._parse_json_or_yaml(cell_specs_file) specs_by_name = {} err = 0 for spec in specs: err_template = _('The field %s is missing from a row in ' '--cell-specs-file') for field in ['name', 'database_connection', 'transport_url']: if field not in spec: err = 1 print(err_template % field) specs_by_name[spec['name']] = spec if err: return 1 # Retrieve existing cells, validate, and index by name cell_mappings = objects.CellMappingList.get_all( context.get_admin_context()) cells_by_name = {} for cell_mapping in cell_mappings: name = getattr(cell_mapping, 'name') if name is None: # TODO(wwriverrat) Can we find a match without raising error? # This will be a common occurrence for those who have used # simple cell setup and the initial cell's name is not set print(_("Error - Existing cell_mapping missing name found. " "Have discovered an existing cell without a name." "This apply_cells function attempts to map your " "specification by name and does not know how to " "handle existing cells without names. Please consider " "calling the cell_v2 update command against any " "existing unnamed cells (ideally matching your spec " "if the cell already exists.")) return 1 else: cells_by_name[cell_mapping.name] = cell_mapping # Use python set functions to determine high-level differences adds = set(specs_by_name.keys()).difference(cells_by_name.keys()) similars = set(specs_by_name.keys()).intersection(cells_by_name.keys()) deletes = set(cells_by_name.keys()).difference(specs_by_name.keys()) result = 0 total_changes = 0 # TODO(wwriverrat) Consider starting txn here and commit when done? # New cells. Add them. for name in adds: cell_spec = specs_by_name[name] if dry_run: print(_("Would have created cell %s with details: %r") % (name, self._masked_cell_spec(cell_spec))) else: add_result = self.create_cell( cell_spec['name'], database_connection=cell_spec['database_connection'], transport_url=cell_spec['transport_url'], verbose=verbose, disabled=self._is_disabled(cell_spec)) print(_("Create cell %s creating cell %s: %r") % ('failed' if add_result else 'succeeded', name, self._masked_cell_spec(cell_spec))) result = max(result, add_result) total_changes += 1 # Cell exists but needs to compare all fields to see if updates needed for name in similars: cell_mapping = cells_by_name[name] cell_spec = specs_by_name[name] changed = False for field in ['database_connection', 'transport_url', 'disabled']: field_changed = getattr(cell_mapping, field) != cell_spec.get(field, None) if field_changed: if field in ['database_connection', 'transport_url']: val_cell = mask_passwd_in_url(getattr(cell_mapping, field)) val_spec = mask_passwd_in_url(cell_spec.get(field)) else: val_cell = getattr(cell_mapping, field) val_spec = cell_spec.get(field) print(_('For cell %s, field %s does not match: cell value ' '(%s) is not same as spec value (%s)') % (cell_mapping.name, field, val_cell, val_spec)) changed = changed or field_changed if changed: if dry_run: print(_("Would have updated cell %s from %r to %r") % (name, self._masked_cell_mapping(cell_mapping), self._masked_cell_spec(cell_spec))) else: # Need to update existing record update_result = self.update_cell( cell_mapping.uuid, name=cell_mapping.name, transport_url=cell_spec['transport_url'], db_connection=cell_spec['database_connection'], disable=self._is_disabled(cell_spec), enable=not self._is_disabled(cell_spec)) print(_("Update cell %s modifying cell %s: %r") % ('failed' if update_result else 'succeeded', name, self._masked_cell_spec(cell_spec))) result = max(result, update_result) total_changes += 1 else: print(_("Cell and spec for %s matches. Nothing to do.") % name) # Cells not in the spec get deleted for name in deletes: cell_mapping = cells_by_name[name] if dry_run: print(_("Would have deleted cell %s with details: %r") % (name, self._masked_cell_mapping(cell_mapping))) else: delete_result = self.delete_cell(cell_mapping.uuid, force=force) if delete_result == 0: print(_("Successfully deleted cell %s: %r") % (name, self._masked_cell_mapping(cell_mapping))) else: print(_("Attempt to delete cell %s (uuid-%s) returned " "unsuccessful response %i. You may wish to " "review and remove all mappings within that " "cell and try again.") % (name, cell_mapping.uuid, result)) result = max(result, delete_result) total_changes += 1 if total_changes: print(_("There were %i changes applied to your cells. You should " "consider restarting services that depend on this " "cell data being up to date (i.e. nova-scheduler, etc).") % total_changes) else: print(_("No changes applied. Your cells are all in sync. Yippee!")) return result @staticmethod def _masked_cell_mapping(cell_mapping): return { 'uuid': cell_mapping.uuid, 'name': cell_mapping.name, 'database_connection': mask_passwd_in_url( cell_mapping.database_connection), 'transport_url': mask_passwd_in_url(cell_mapping.transport_url), 'disabled': cell_mapping.disabled, } @staticmethod def _masked_cell_spec(cell_info): db = cell_info.get('database_connection', None) xport = cell_info.get('transport_url', None) return { 'name': cell_info.get('name', None), 'database_connection': None if not db else mask_passwd_in_url(db), 'transport_url': None if not xport else mask_passwd_in_url(xport), 'disabled': cell_info.get('disabled') } @staticmethod def _is_disabled(cell_spec, default=False): return cell_spec.get('disabled', default) in [True, 'true', 'True', '1', 'yes', 'on'] @staticmethod def _parse_json_or_yaml(file_location): """Parse the raw contents of a data file. Parses the contents of a file which can be in either yaml or json format. Both can be parsed as yaml. :param file_location: A string containing a path to a file of json or yaml format. :returns: The file contents converted to python objects. """ try: with open(file_location) as fh: parsed = yaml.safe_load(fh) except yaml.YAMLError as e: raise ValueError(six.text_type(e)) return parsed or []

commit_message:
Better handle live migration abort

Some drivers do not support abort. The base driver raises
NotImplementedError for the live_migration_abort. This may
result in the instance state being changed to ERROR which
renders additional operations on the instance as
problematic (until the admin resets the bad state)

The solution to this issues is two fold:
1. Compute virt driver - enable the driver to set a flag
   indicating if it can support abort for a live migration.
   The new flag is supports_live_migration_abort and this is
   False by default. If the compute driver does not support
   the opertaion the compute manager will raise the exception:
   AbortMigrationNotSupported
2. On the API side if the exception AbortMigrationNotSupported is
   raised by the manager then the API server will return
   BadRequest. Prior to this it was getting a random 500.

Closes-bug: #1815466
Change-Id: I9b66765045568033c18b1a5780601e56c4c70e66

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-10-29 20:36:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_congress/commit/4ae518bafec970ef3030c4bffb8c5b1c6fdb602b', 'message': "Remove opensuse-150 job

Remove the opensuse-150 job, it is not run anymore on master and was

commit_message:
Switch to opensuse-15

opensuse-150 nodeset is referring to openSUSE 15.0, which is still in
maintenance but openSUSE 15.1 has been released already. "opensuse-15"
is going to refer to the "latest openSUSE 15.x" build released and
working for OpenStack going forward, so add this nodeset and use
it by default going forward.

Note this is not a backport, master has changed the job setup completly,
instead it just updates the jobs.

Change-Id: Ia6e1341dd93a2cbf78179d1064b924b4d3126470
